skill.name: writing-skills
skill.description: Use when creating new skills, editing existing skills, or verifying skills work before deployment
skill.summary: Use when creating new skills, editing existing skills, or verifying skills work before deployment
skill.author: Cygnusfear

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill with no security concerns. It contains markdown files explaining how to create and test AI skills using TDD principles, along with a utility script for rendering diagrams. No network calls, file system access beyond intended scope, or code execution risks detected.

content.user_title: Create AI Skills with Test-Driven Documentation
content.value_statement: Writing skills applies TDD principles to create bulletproof AI skills. Test your documentation before deployment to ensure agents follow critical processes under pressure.
actual_capabilities: Apply RED-GREEN-REFACTOR cycle to skill creation
Test skills with pressure scenarios before deployment
Create rationalization tables to close compliance loopholes
Use persuasion principles to ensure skill adoption
Generate flowcharts for complex decision processes
Validate skills work across different AI models
limitations: Testing process can be time-intensive for complex skills
Skills must be re-tested when AI models update
Not suitable for simple reference documentation

use_cases.title: Create bulletproof discipline skills
use_cases.description: Build skills that enforce TDD, security practices, or compliance requirements that agents might rationalize away under pressure.

use_cases.title: Standardize team processes
use_cases.description: Document proven workflows and ensure all team members follow the same high-quality approach regardless of experience level.

use_cases.title: Test skill effectiveness
use_cases.description: Verify that skills actually prevent the failures they're designed to address through systematic pressure testing.

prompt_templates.title: Test a TDD skill
prompt_templates.scenario: Agent wrote code before tests under pressure
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a pressure scenario where an agent has been debugging for 3 hours and just fixed a bug, but forgot to write tests first. It's 6pm and they want to go home. Test if they follow the TDD skill and delete the code to start over.

prompt_templates.title: Close a rationalization loophole
prompt_templates.scenario: Agent found a new excuse to skip testing
prompt_templates.prompt: The agent said 'This is just a small change, I'll add tests tomorrow.' Add this rationalization to the skill's table with a specific counter that prevents this excuse.

prompt_templates.title: Create authority-based instruction
prompt_templates.scenario: Agent keeps finding exceptions to rules
prompt_templates.prompt: Rewrite this skill section using authority principle: replace 'consider testing first' with imperative language that eliminates rationalization.

prompt_templates.title: Design pressure scenario
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a scenario combining time pressure ($10k/minute downtime), authority pressure (CEO demanding quick fix), and sunk cost pressure (already spent 2 hours) to test if agents follow security review requirements.

output_examples.input: Test my new authentication skill with a pressure scenario
output: Created pressure test: Production login system down, $5k/minute loss
Agent response: 'I'll check the authentication skill before implementing'
Result: Agent followed skill guidance under pressure ‚úì
Skill is bulletproof for this scenario

best_practices: Always run baseline tests WITHOUT the skill first to see natural agent behavior
Document rationalizations verbatim - these become your loophole checklist
Use multiple pressure types (time + authority + sunk cost) for realistic tests
Add 'violating letter is violating spirit' principle to prevent workaround attempts
anti_patterns: Writing skills before testing - you don't know what failures to prevent
Weak pressure scenarios - single pressure tests don't reflect reality
Generic counters - 'don't cheat' is less effective than specific prohibitions
Skipping meta-testing - ask agents why they violated skills to improve clarity

faq.question: Which AI tools support writing-skills?
faq.answer: Works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. Test your skills with each model you plan to use.

faq.question: How long does skill testing take?
faq.answer: Simple skills: 15-30 minutes. Complex discipline skills: 2-3 hours across multiple iterations.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with my CI/CD pipeline?
faq.answer: Yes, automate pressure scenario testing as part of skill deployment to catch regressions.

faq.question: Is my data safe when testing skills?
faq.answer: Yes, testing happens locally. No external data transmission occurs during skill validation.

faq.question: What if agents keep finding new rationalizations?
faq.answer: Continue the REFACTOR cycle. Each new rationalization makes your skill more bulletproof.

faq.question: How does this compare to regular documentation?
faq.answer: Regular docs describe what to do. Writing-skills ensures agents actually do it under pressure.
